We look forward to seeing you on Monday evening at 7 PM for the School Reopening Virtual Parent/Community Meeting!

post_text: Yesterday 11/4 we hosted the Calpulli Dance Company as a culminating celebration of the Hispanic Heritage study our FLES students have been engaged in grades 2-5. Prior to yesterday’s assembly, our 5th graders listened to songs from each one of the Spanish-speaking countries around the world rating their favorite one. 2nd, 3rd, and 4th graders are also immersed in the Spanish language each day, learning how to communicate with Spanish speakers around the world. The Calpulli Mexican Dance Company visited our school to help us explore the diverse genre of Mexican folkloric dance through their performances. They used unique costumes and music to perform distinct choreographies from various states and ethnic regions in Mexico. A huge “thank you” to our FLES teachers Ms. Paterra & Ms. Coulehan for their efforts in making this possible.

Google Expedition Experience!
This was an amazing kindergarten experience, where we entered many of the ecosystems we are studying in science. We made connections to our learning, and got to see how the animals and plants survive in these different environments. These virtual reality goggles brought us right into the ecosystems and we felt that we were in their world. We asked questions as if we were scientists and shared our learning. It was an exciting experience!

December 11, 2017 at 7:38 PM ·

DFSD recently hosted a 1/2 day workshop for the Rivertowns school districts, presented by NEMNET Founder & CEO Warren Reid, focusing on the challenges, best practices and strategies associated with diversity faculty recruitment . Superintendents, Principals and other personnel directly involved in "hiring" staff attended the presentation and talked about expanding their minority recruitment efforts. The participants learned how and where to access information and resources that will assist them in meeting their diversity goals and left with concrete strategies for success. December 4, 2017 at 4:17 PM ·

Mrs. Coren's 3rd grade students were scattered around the classroom studying about and responding to the question "How do Bullfrogs Survive?" This was part of an ELA module using a science lesson on informational writing.But most interesting of all was the room's alternative seating arrangement.

Students were engrossed in the assignment while working at standing desks, sitting desks, at small group tables, in the classroom library, standing at the window and even laying on the floor! Research has shown that the biggest benefit to students who use alternative seating options in their classrooms include better attention/focus, less restlessness, and increased participation. Must be something to this...the students were on-task and thoroughly enjoying the research activity!

It is so cool to witness these great minds at work!!
